prompt.body: When was the age of Greeks and Romans?

prompt.body:
Read the box with the words on page 34. Which two words are missing in the next list?

Catholic Church - Utopia - The Praise of Folly - Act of Supremacy - Anglican Church

content.body: What is the name of the first paragraph? Greek
What is the name of the second paragraph? humanism

Put the following sentences in the past continuous. You form the past continuous by

using was/were + verb + ing.

1 The Greeks scientists (to study) nature, when the came up with new ideas.

2 Most of them (to look) with human reason to the world, while in particular Greek citizens still believed in myths and gods.

3 People (to call) them humanist after these philosophers argued that humans give meaning to their own world.

4 Like Thales and Xenophanes (to argue): human thinking and not supernatural gods are the key to knowledge.

5 In the Middle Ages the Catholic Church (to try) to let the Europeans forget about these ideas.

6 But during the Renaissance in the fourteenth century, Italians scientist like Petrarch (to copy) and translating the classical manuscripts.

prompt.body: What does the word 'humanism' means? Use the wordlist on page 56.

prompt.body: Put the next events in the right order, start with the oldest event. (Use page 166-167, the names of the ages)

content.body: In the first urban communities, knowledge was mostly aimed at understanding the will of the gods.
The Romans improved and multiplied the Greek way of scientific thinking, their scientist wrote in Latin which kept on the linqua franca for centuries.
The monks in the monasteries were copying ancient texts and books by hand, but only the works from ancient scholars who fitted in the Catholic religion.
The hunter-gatherers and the first farmers were living in the prehistory, knowledge was passed on oral.
In Italy during the 15th century, the rich merchants became interested in their own history which led to a revival of interests in the classical scholars.
In the poleis, in particular Athens, philosophers started to question religious beliefs and used their reason and senses to understand the world.

prompt.body: About who are the third and the fifth paragraph in this section? Choose two scholars.

content.body: is known as the 'Father of humanism'. He had one of the biggest collections of texts in Europe at that time. According to Petrarch, God wanted humans to use his intelligence, curiosity and creativity. According to his opinion, nothing showed this more than rediscovering and translating them. Not surprisingly, this had one of the biggest collections of Greek and Roman texts at that time. And despite the faults he found made by the Church, he remained Catholic. Another famous humanist further in time was who was also criticising the excesses of the . He was promoting a more personal between people and God. And, just like Petrarch, he believed the Catholic Church should from within.

True/ false 1 Petrarch favorite authors were Cicero, Livy and Virgil

True / false 2 Petrarch can be seen as the Founding Father of Humanism

True / false 3 Petrarch wrote The Praise of Folly to criticise the Church

True / false 4 Erasmus lived between 1600-1700 and was born in Rotterdam

True / false 5 Erasmus believed people should read the Bible in Latin

Petrarch wrote a letter, whch is called: 'The ascent of Mount Ventoux' (1336):

'... the mountain is visible from a great distance, was ever before my eyes, and I conceived the plan of some time doing what I have at last accomplished today (climbing the mountain). The idea took hold upon me with special force when, in rereading Livy's History of Rome (an ancient Roman historian), yesterday, I happened upon the place where Philip the Macedon, the same who waged war against the Romans, ascended Mount Haemus in Thessaly. '

Choose two lines, both about 'classical learning'.

The Italian humanist Pico, count of Mirandola, wrote in the 'Oration on the Dignity of Man' (1486):

'I have read the records of the Arabian, reverend fathers, that this Abdala the Saracen, when questioned as to what on this stage of the world, as it were, could be seen most worthy of wonder, he replied: 'There is nothing to be seen more wonderful than man.'

Choose two lines which deal about the source about the changing worldview in the sixteenth century.

items.value: Oration on the Dignity of Man
the records of the Arabian, reverend fathers
'There is nothing to be seen more wonderful than man.'

prompt.body:
Christopher Columbus wrote on his journal 'The Third Voyage' (1492):

'... in supporting this opinion... that it agrees with that of Seneca (a Roman historian) and says that Aristotle had been enable to gain information respecting the world by means of Alexander the Great, and Seneca by the emperor Nero, and Pliny (another Roman historian) through the Romans.'

Which characteristic aspects fit with the source about the discoverer Columbus?

content.body: The start of the European expansion
The Dutch Revolt and the birth of the independend Dutch state.

prompt.body: Make combinations between meaning and the words.

content.body: The main religion in Europe since the Roman Empire.
Philosophical point of view in which human beings have control over their lives; it places critical thinking and reason over religion.
The methods and ideas used by the ancient Greeks and Romans to study the world.
The language and dialect spoken by the ordinary people in a region.
A period in history that is seen as the rebirth of antiquity.
The way a person interprets the world
A device that made it possible to copy texts faster and more easily than before.
